summary: Obsessed with UFOs, a man (Reid Warner) and two friends find evidence of an alien presence at Area 51 in Nevada.

wonderful and excellent movie!
Good movie. Nice and wonderful

Apesar da técnica super batida, câmera na mão, imagem tremida, escuridão, documentário fake, eu amo esses terror B, sobre a área 52, Ets e afins, jovens curiosos e inconsequentes, ficou meio chato do meio para o fim sobrevivi aos trancos, o desfecho interessante, fraco, dos mais fracos sobre o assunto, mas valeu perder uns minutos por ele...

Oren Peli and Steven Spielberg both had very similar visions of Area 51 (aliens, military base, etc.). And while I loved the lore, but didn't really like how it played out in Kingdom of the Crystal Skull... Area 51 is 'The Room' version of that KOTC intro.
It was bad until the middle of it, but by the end it was just fckn sad. Don't know who wrote this movie but investigate at least a little bit the next time. Don't waste your time watching this crap.

I was so upset how not bad it was.
-Sergei Michailowitsch Eisenstein

If they were going for a comedy, I would give this a 5 star review, but this is by far the worst horror/thriller I have ever seen in my life. Not only is it incomprehensible, it makes absolutely no sense. I bought this for 5 dollars at big lots, so I feel like that just goes to show how bad it is. My friends and I watched this movie and made constant fun of it, it was so bad. 5/5 comedy, but not at all good otherwise.
Slow Moving and a lot of use of found footage this movie is a total bore, why anyone would make this movie is beyond me, I gave the Blair Witch Project a 1/2 star too!

What you expect from an amateur-like found-footage horror. It has a pretty generic story, starring some young people who don't know the consequences of their actions and end up running for their lives, but this doesn't make the movie bad already. The problem was the predictable motivation of these characters. The film also has a flawed script with the tiring repetition of predictable phrases like "what the f*ck" or "move, move". To finish with the negative aspects, it results unnecessarily long, having action only in the final 40 minutes. Not gonna lie, it had its entertaining moments because of its special effects and its film locations, which resembled the Area 51 that many people have in mind. It was quite fun, but as it has more negative than positive aspects, I feel obligated to give it a 5, which means a "Rotten" score.

I think it was very creative. Nobody has ever filmed a movie about people sneaking into Area 51 and the special effects are kinda cool and makes the movie very creepy and makes us think about what Lurks Inside the government files and in Area 51 itself. Everybody knows we are not alone and this movie is worth watching.

Area 51 was a fun ride. Some parts were enjoyable, others not. But when they get to the bases, it is very silly and dumb. But in an entertaining way. So this is not a big surprise. Like I said before in my review of JeruZalem: Grab  a group of friends, watch this movie, and you will have a good time. But don't expect a action-packed, scary as hell, excellent horror movie. It's decent.
improves considerably once the protagonists make their way into the (poorly fortified) compound
Premesse che danno un minimo di speranza a questo found footage che però, soffre terribilmente l'assenza di personaggi interessanti che portano verso un finale decisamente di difficile comprensione.

This one's almost a good movie. The most entertaining parts of the film take place at Area 51 itself, where the production values and the atmosphere are so convincing that one could think the real Area 51 could look like this. What they find there is something of a mixed-bag, since although we did not know for certain what they would find, we are not surprised.

But the biggest disappointment is the characters who, in spite of some fecklessly colorful dialogue and behavior, come off as generic frat-boy types. What's curious is that although the main characters spend most of the film planning or discussing how to break into Area 51, they do not seriously seem to consider the magnitude of what they're saying, even when one of them insists that the penalty for getting caught is 15 years in prison. I forget, also, if they ever mentioned an escape plan.

The pacing is another issue. Too much time is spent on the heroes planning and talking about motion sensors, and arguing about protagonist Reid's (Reid Warner), immovable determination to invade the base. After an hour, especially with such uninteresting characters, this feels like too much. There are a handful of moments pre-Area 51 that work. There's the scene in which the young heroes break into the home of a base employee and must sneak back out after the family comes home. But even then that's sort of minimal-level suspense. If we had cared more about the characters, or sympathized with their motives, scenes like this would be more.

I admit to being confused by the camera footage perspective of the film, which at some point shows multiple people splitting in several directions, each with a camera recording for the audience's benefit. Since these cameras are likely destroyed or lost by the end of the film, how can anyone see it? Are we seeing what the cameras are seeing as they're happening? Found footage veterans will know the answers.

My recommendation? Give the characters more involving motivations, let those motivations guide the plot in unexpected ways, and spend a reasonable amount of time planning, invading, and encountering Area 51 and its inhabitants.
It was good enough and it just ended abruptly

Well, certainly it's not a cinematic masterpiece of any sort. But:
a) it's professionally shot
b) the plot is not garbage
c) the CGI is excellent
d) it's a rare genre of sci-fi horror hence every decent film in this genre is a treat for devotees
e) MOST IMPORTANTLY: to my taste, it's absolutely watchable, quite engaging, quite scary (the director is a renowned master of horrors) and I don't regret a second spent watching it.

I thought it was the best movie Ive ever seen in my life i thought sonic cgi was good but this is on another level this cgi really made me believe i was part of the area 51 raid I wish they made a second one but they obivous cant because that ending was so good that it would ruin the movie if they made a second one its like how pacific rim 2 was a piece of poop this movie inspires me to live until september 20th i was gonna kill myself today but i didnt after watching this god bless director 10/10 fresh must see
This was good. The same as Paranormal Activity was and in someways better. I'm a film snob and yes like alll kinds and this is good. Low budget of course but still good.

So bad, and filmed in the almost pitch black, so it was more funny and cliche ridden than anything. And if I had a dime for every time one of the characters said, "F**K!" or "What the f**k?" I would be a millionaire! Nothing is original or even compelling.
Une conclusion gâchée par des effets spéciaux ridicules et un scénario bâclé. Dommage...

I must go and visit the most famous army test base because its security is piss poor and you can literally walk in the place and scream and run up loud stairs without anyone noticing that you are in the place this film looks good from the trailers but turns out to be a complete borefest I was looking forward to the film but was ultimately let down yet again

Area 51 has some decent moments but the actors didn't do anything to help the movie.  It bothers me they were able to break in easily into one of the most protected bases in the USA.  Heck, I think they even shoot pigeons if they get too close!  
     I also think it would have been better to get more explanation as to what those things where in those glass enclosures.  The movie could have been better if they aliens had been shown a little bit more on the screen.  The ending is too sudden...how about a look into the craft?  Did they survive?  Not terrible, but BAD overall.   2/5  OR  4/10

Found footage films are difficult to get a good rating. There are only a few good ones out there for example, Blair witch, district 9 and clover field. I know this has bad reviews but give it a chance it is quit interesting even though there are quite a few rough patches. Acting isn't the best as is everything but the plot and concept of the film. Not much like it. Hard to decide if I like it or not.

Area 51 is the perfect example of how not to make a found footage film. The first half of the film is needlessly spend watching the group preparing for their trip to Area 51. This could easily have been done in 15 minutes so quite how it was dragged out to 45 minutes is beyond me as nothing happens at all. The next 20-25 minutes of tedium are spent with the group finally entering and looking around an incredibly poorly secured Area 51 all whilst showing the viewer nothing of interest. Things finally kick-off in the last 20-25 minutes but the camera is so shaky that it's not that easy to tell what is actually happening.

Wasn't all bad, gave me what I wanted and a bit more, good ending, with a twist on what might be inside the base.  I'd call it an Area 51 cheeseburger with extra pickles, i.e tastes as I'd expect but gave me some more on the side.

I almost shat myself watching this.
Some interesting ideas and visuals are squandered thanks to the super shaky found-footage film-making.
The worst of the worst!

I'm giving this 5 to balance out some of the negative scores,  watched this on Netflix where it had 1 star (so I went into it expecting nothing) 

I was presently surprised 


spoilers below (but only a little) 

1) Yeah area 51 was not as guarded as it could of been but they literally had to build stealth suits get near it and they have I'd cards, secret maps from an ex employee and finger prints for scanners so what more do you want from a Sci fi film? - if we're gonna point out flaws in Sci fi films well be here till the end of time 

2) Yeah it takes a while to build up,  but that's building the suspension and also explaining how they even think they might get in - it's nice not to see a film run in guns blazing and the build up i found very enjoyable 

3) ending - it ends like so many films and tv shows do with out an explanation - but I thought that was executed well as it leaves a lot open and don't need one, uch better ending that Blair witch or the sopranos 


4) 2nd watch,  when watching with out expectations you would probably focus more on the plot and other weird bits like the floating rock and alien ship (they were very very cool) 


5) possible sequel,  ending easy made a 2nd film possible 


6) better than all the fast and furious films, the hills have eyes 2 and jeepers creepers - screw the hype,  go in with no expectations and you'll have an enjoyable ride 

all the best

It is very regular since it has flaws very strong script but the idea of ??Area 51 is well achieved by good performances in this production there

Heavily into conspiracy theories so I thought this would be the film for me! The film is in a paranormal activity first person layout. It's tense at parts and exciting throughout although the ending is terrible!
I didn't hate it but this genre is done.

An intriguing concept and a well made film. It has some good ideas, but the ending totally lost me.

the only thing this movie did was show how tired the found footage genre is. it presents everything wrong with that type of horror film now and and presents everything wrong with the horror genre. it's lazy, uninspired, completely un scary and tension free. it takes about an hour for something to actually happen, and when something does happen it's just dumb. the CGI is horrendous, the acting is terrible and the script is laughably bad. Area 51 is a prime example of what's wrong with the horror genre nowadays and recycles every possible found footage and horror cliche they can think of. don't waste your time.

For a low budget movie this was pretty decent. It helps if your fascinated with the extraterrestrial theory and Area 51. One day at a party a young student goes missing for some of the night and all he knows is he is being drawn towards Area 51

It's actually very entertaining. It's just not very plausible, the fact that these guys could just run around Area 51 without much surveillance. Yes, eventually alarms go off but I mean this is Area 51 and to just be able to wander around as much as they did doesn't really seem realistic. The final act is also a little lazy I think but the first couple acts are very suspenseful regardless and given the amount of shit found footage films out there now, this one really isn't that bad.
Though well-researched, I was more entertained by "Batman & Robin" and "Battlefield: Earth" than I was by this film.
Though well-researched, I was more entertained by "Batman & Robin" and "Battlefield: Earth" than I was by this film.
For UFO conspiracy theorist this movie will prove to be an exciting ride! Obviously flawed, but hey, it's Hollywood (sort of).
Too bad. The subject was interesting and could have been made into a better movie. Nothing happens, and for a long time. And when things start to happen, it's too little, too late.

I liked the movie but the first half hour needed to be written differently. I felt like the actors and actress could have wore helmet cameras rather than a shaky mess. I think a remake of this movie would do well if they let me do it.

I didn't think this movie was as bad as everyone was making out, sure it's very generic and doesn't nothing to further the genre, but it's still enjoyable and has a fair few good moments in it. Definitely not the worst found footage movie I've seen.

Area 51 reminds me of The Signal, both are sci-fi mysteries concerning alien visitations to earth. As you can figure out from the title, Area 51 is the story of 4 guys who develop a sudden craving to not just learn about area 51 but to visit it in actuality. It's filmed in the currently popular mock documentary style and opens with interviews of the 4 guys' friends by an unknown person. Then the movie cuts to the guys' home made camera footage. How this footage was obtained, in light of the concluding events, is unknown as well.
The advantage of the guys' jerky home made movies is that it covers up the movie's low quality special effects. The guys prepare for the mission but are curiously unprepared for what they are convinced that they will find at area 51.
It's pretty fun and fortunately short at 1:30 and has a mild political undertow to it.
Besides the lack of cinematography, what really hampers the movie is the dialogue. There are enough f-bombs in it for WWIII. Typical dialogue is: "(f-bpmb) we've got to get out of here. (f-bomb) did you see that ? (f-bomb) we've got to get out of here (f-bomb)...." ad nauseum. A little bit like an ad libs version of Waiting for Godot.
It was ok....makes you think tho.....hmmm....

finally, the much anticipated follow up from the director of the first paranormal activity, idk why it took so long for this to get released, but its another found footage film, ill say its cut above most found footage style films these days, in terms of the production design and effects, and the actors are pretty decent, like paranormal activity its a slow burn, but its too slow, they dont even get to area 51 till halfway through, and shit really doesnt start going down til the final 20 min, and then its too little too late, i did like the design of the bunker/base, and some of the alien technolgies were pretty cool, but there needed to be more of a payoff
Took an hour to set up, dialogue was poor, lack of "alien" screen time, far fetched plot line, and terrible ending.  What a waste of a good premise.
Honestly feel like I'm the only person that legitimately enjoyed and loved this movie. Thought it was great, unbelievable at times, and excluding the crappy abrupt ending.

Area 51 - 3 college student aged kids sneaking into one of the most secure compounds on Earth and being chased, caught and flown up up and away by something other than human in a disc craft. There is the notion that ET's are here to mess you up. Ordinarily I'd play with that a while if I hadn't learned years ago that they were here before only to assist our pitiful race. Watch it if you wish. I was underwhelmed and disenchanted with a mere continuation of Extraterrestrial propaganda.

What can I say! I'm a complete sucker for well done found footage films. You absolutely have to leave all plausibility at the door even though it's shooting for believability, but I always am engrossed with them for some reason. I wouldn't recommend it to other people who don't dig the genre, but I was entertained almost the whole way through. A huge problem for a lot of these films is they can never really stuck their endings. Always seems to fall apart incredibly bad towards the ends.

The first thing I did after watching "Area 51," directed by Oren Peli, was to check the picture's budget. I was horrified that five million dollars was put into the film but it looked like it had a budget of about five thousand dollars. It is very student film-by one who is meant to fail the class because he or she does not understand how to set up elementary elements, like how to create tension or suspense. This is key because the genre is sci-fi horror but the result is, for the most part, boredom.

It starts off on the wrong foot. People talk directly to camera about how three friends-Reid (Reid Warner), Darrin (Darrin Bragg), and Ben (Ben Rovner)-had gone missing ever since they decided to break into Area 51, a government facility that supposedly house extraterrestrial evidence. This is a mistake because it signals to us that it is one of those so-called found-footage pictures where it all goes terribly wrong in the end-meaning there is likely no survivor. Already we get the impression that it is a pessimistic film.

One might be tempted to compare this work to Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sánchez' "The Blair Witch Project." After all, they have more than a few similarities: three protagonists, characters going on a journey in search of proof, and they come to regret their decision to plunge carelessly into the unknown. But to make that comparison is an insult to the 1999 classic. That film has plenty of memorable scenes. It may frustrate many at times but one cannot stop looking at it because there is a quiet menace underneath the desperation of the characters.

Here, just about everything comes across as forced and false. For instance, as the protagonists finally arrive at the facility, one can barely see anything. The break-in occurs at night so it is very dark. In addition, the hand-held camera shakes so relentlessly that it is dizzying and we are unable to appreciate the environment or marvel at the government's secret area. There is an exchange among the characters that the point of them going on this mission is to show the public what is hidden. I found it ironic that in the end it shows us nothing of substance.

The visual effects during the latter half are ugly and fake: floating meteorites, seemingly conscious liquid, spaceships-even invisible extraterrestrials (how convenient-it must have been so expensive creating invisible aliens on screen). One of the problems with these images is a complete lack of imagination. These are things that we have seen before in better television shows and movies. Peli's film does not bother to be creative or offer something new. It takes tired images and formulas, chews them up, and regurgitates them. Then the filmmakers, through our eyes and brain, expect us to digest these recycled trash. Don't you find that insulting?

Halfway through the picture, something in me-one who knows better-wished that I were watching the Season One finale of Chris Carter's "The X-Files." That one episode is everything this movie is not: sharply written, imaginative, envelope-pushing in terms of the medium, the performances are memorable, and the revelations stick with you like a sentient goo from outer space.

some aspects of this movie were cool, the plan to infiltrate the base was pretty interesting but in real life the base is near impossible to get into undetected, they use much more security systems then what is said that they use in this movie. after they got inside area 51 I think the movie went downhill, the storyline became dull and it got boring watching them just run around seemingly aimlessly yet still finding where they needed to go with ease. the acting was pretty good but the way the storyline went from kind of realistic to completely unrealistic left alot to be desired. could of been a much better movie, also a pretty lame predictable ending but can't expect much else from a found footage movie. not worth watching.

really disappointed you never even get to see the Aliens up close or clearly. also, I'm pretty sure Area 51 would have more than just 5 people working any given night. lastly, anybody who is tresspassing on Area 51 is shot.

Leaves "Impact" For The Viewer To Watch Towards The End,And I Did Not Know "Squidward Tentacles" Was In This Movie!

Area 51 is an enjoyable found footage style film about a group of teens trying to discover the secrets to the mysterious Area 51.  

It is very intriguing, despite its very slow start.  The planning that the group put in to evade the security of the base is very well thought out and feels very spy-ish.

However, once they get onto the base, the characters seem to leave any intelligent thought behind.  

The security of the base is inconsistent as well.  They have ammonia detectors, heat sensors, etc outside the base to prevent people from getting in undetected, but there was no security inside the base.  No cameras, microphones etc.  It felt disjointed.

The last half hour is very exciting and lots of fun, however, so some of the illogic can be forgiven.
The trailer makes it look great! Until you press play for the actual movie. Major let down.

I'm a sucker for movies like this about aliens. It wasn't anything special until they finally breeched the strangely under-protected facility, but that's about 58 min into it. Then it was reasonably tense. Some neat special effects with the ufos & their tech, but I would have liked to have seen a bit more if the aliens themselves.
It's bad. Really bad. Like "choose another movie before this one" bad.

This movie suffered from the typical found footage problems. It spent too long getting to the freaky stuff, then didn't really deliver freaky stuff, and then didn't put enough budget to the antagonists of the movie (this time aliens). It's really a shame because it seemed like had they gotten more creative, it could have been interesting, but alas they went for middle of the road boring

WOW was this bad. The editing is sloppy, choppy and just all around terrible. It comes across like those involved with the film just didn't care. The main characters are your typical found footage douchy bros with a cute female thrown in (Who's only characteristic is she's cute). The film itself follows many of your typical beats (it goes pretty much exactly where you think it would go. No real twists, turns, surprises, or even scares). You know your movie is in trouble when the douche-iest bro is the only one who starts talking sense. I wasn't crazy about Paranormal Activity, but at least it used it's minimalistic settings to its advantage (Here we get to explore your typical office, locker room, office staircase, and a few tunnels), was competently made, and actually had some scares. Not to mention the CGI and effects in Area 51  (when there are any) are super weak. There are a few pieces that could have come across as clever in better hands. In the end, Area 51 is just a bunch of stupid 20-somethings wandering around, doing nothing, with absolutely nothing happening until it's predictable and laughably bad ending finally comes around. A very unimpressive, boring, and dull film that travels in a straight line from beginning to end. Area 51 could have been a really cool film, and it's premise does hold potential (even if it has been done before). Unfortunately, this is just your dime-a-dozen, paint-by-numbers, lifeless and listless found-footage style movie. No wonder it never got a theatrical release.
what the heck did I just watch???
Disappointed that we never got to see the Aliens at all for all of the build up in getting inside.
What a waste of an hour and a half of my life.  The plot is weak, and you really don't see anything either.  Don't waste your time.

given Peli and his hit with Paranormal Activity, I expected more.  instead there's this unoriginal alien movie that doesn't give us anything new.  aleins are the same plain grey, big eyed, big headed things everyone thinks of, the actions leading up to the last act is pretty unbelievable and the ending was just crap.  skippable.

I watched that entire movie and they couldn't show me ONE alien? Not one redeeming factor. Uncreative, unrealistic, and boring. Seriously, it's not even one of those movies you can just have fun with when you're bored.

There is no sense to be made of the plot so don't try. It is one of the only movies I have watched filmed with a Samsung Galaxy smartphone. To keep costs down they didn't edit. I guess they were trying to keep it real.
With some movies like this I suggest getting as drunk as the director but it would be a waste of even the cheapest stuff you could find.
A redeeming feature, cause I always try to find something, tell one of your friends you found the lost footage of Area 51 that proves that aliens have visited earth!
I am not a fan of the "found footage" film style, so that was against this one from the beginning...but I was hoping this one would actually be good. It was not.
Just awful, just so very awful

Alors que l'idée de base est plutôt sympa pour les amateurs la célèbre Area 51 , le film quand à lui est malheureusement plus un échec. Si les acteurs se débrouille pas trops mal et le film en lui même est plutôt bien tourné, le scénario est très peu intéressant , mis a part peut-être quand les jeunes sont dans la base. La fin du film est loufoque et on se demande vraiment si pénétrer dans cet endroit serais aussi "facile?" (Évidemment que non!)

"From the makers of Paranormal Activity!!"
My reply: Yeah, it shows. Nothing new or creative here that hasn't been done much better elsewhere. (The lamely titled "Alien Abduction" from 2014, and "Extraterrestrial" from the same year, just to name a couple.)

You can pretty easily spot where the original footage ends and the reshoots begin (when the footage jumps dramatically in quality... and the actors magically age between cuts) but it all gels into a sometimes intense, pretty intriguing little ride.
intense suspense throughought entire movie, but a poor ending
Half-decent setup but the pay-off is lame.
Could of been scarier..

It starts off as every found footage film you have seen with lazy character writing and the basic set up, but as it goes along the way it brings us some tension. But in the end as every founfd footage film, the payoff isn't worth the price.

The entire first act of this film was a total waste of screen time. I really have enjoyed Oren Peli's work in the past, but somehow he just lost all sense of pace and atmosphere on this one.

The whole first twenty minutes or so of this mess could be cut out and it wouldn't effect the overall story at all. There's a party scene where it's implied the story's lead is abducted/probed by aliens, and they've told him to come to Area 51 or something. That would be interesting if it ever came up ever again. Getting the characters to Area 51 is the easy part when writing a movie like this. You have a trio of people going in, and the driver waiting outside who changed his mind about going in.

Okay, so, why not just write it as a band of misfits who develop a strong fascination with Area 51 and decide that they want to see inside? It would lead to less wasted time, and more time for us to be scared while they're actually in Area 51.

Truth be told, I have no real overall opinion on this movie. See it if you like or don't. Man, this is a shame, because "Paranormal Activity" is one of the best horror movies in ages.

A slow, boring trip to nowhere. I can see why this almost did not get released. How could a subject so intriguing be depicted with so little imagination? The phrase "Time waster" was made for this movie.

I think I have gone on a rant on why I love found footage films many times before, so I am going to avoid that here. Despite, the failing hype around the genre due to some really terrible made movies, you may expect something else from this one as its a return to direction from writer/ producer of the Insidious series, the unfairly cancelled brilliant TV series The River - Oren Peli. The man behind the camera of the 1st Paranormal Activity, the film which arguably started this craze (yeah I know Blair Witch!). Of course for a fan like me, this film was awaited on completely different level as its combined two of my favorite genres (found footage & Aliens conspiracy). Ghosts and aliens scare me, and classic terror tropes work wonders on me! Ever since the overrated "Blair Witch Project," we have been deluged with similar-themed films; most of which fall way, way short of being anything but tiresome. So enter Oren Peli with his own take on the concept, but in his favor we have the mysterious and always-intriguing Area 51 as the backdrop. That fact alone is precisely why I decided to give this film a look. But unfortunately, just like every poor film of the genre, the film lacks any depth & adding to the mix is the poor finale. It suffers from the same exact problems by stuttering towards the end! The story follows Reid (Reid Warner) who after a 'calling' during a pool part convinces his friends Darrin (Darrin Bragg) & Ben (Ben Rovner) to take him to Las Vegas & help him break into the mythical government facility Area 51 in order to expose the presence of Aliens on earth. Along with them on the ride is fellow conspiracy theorist Jelena (Jelena Nik), whose deceased father was an ex employee at the facility. So we get the usual footage of people driving to desolate areas, where they are confronted by suspicious looking people, they talk to other people with whom are also obsessed with the subject matter, and this happens for the majority of the film! For most early parts, the film delivers quite the ride as audiences follow these guys on Vegas and its surrounding. Some investigations and interviews set the tone right, and not in overly silly way. Characters are also pretty decent and likable as though they are real life friends. Unfortunately, it soon arrives at familiar territory of hazy shots and mindless running. The scenes in the city or desert are identifiable, but when it is stranded in dark corners, the movie loses the momentum significantly. Script is also numbingly bland as characters would yell the same thing over and over again, this is especially true when they are repeatedly shouting, "We gotta go". With both visual and audio decrease in quality, it just turns into a confusing escapade. At first it appeared that Peli might have done it right. Blending actors and sets with real people and locations associated with Area 51, the set-up is intriguing. Even the process in which these filmmakers attempt to foil some of the high-tech base security systems, seems plausible. So far so good. But it is when the title characters break into the house of an Area 51 / S4 worker and steal his 'card', eventually actually getting inside the top-secret facility, that the movie becomes completely unbelievable and downright ridiculous. Everything that follows is what we have come to know, and depending on how you feel about these shaky-cam movies, love or hate about the concept. Cinematography is to be expected from this kind of found footage flick, it's rather elementary, but there are a few good shots with modified vision. At several scenes the film builds up the suspense pretty well, these are not all translated into thrilling moments. It almost seems like it has problems in latter half, resorting to cheap alien gimmick and nullifying its early decent production. There are some decent and pretty good Area 51 alien movies and "documentaries" out there, but this one is just not one of them. It's just more of the same old, same old found footage where nothing worthwhile happens until the last 15 minutes or so and even when something does finally happen, it's a huge disappointment. For what this was hyped up to be, it was a huge disappointment, but I wasn't surprised honestly. If you want to waste an hour watching the build up to a half hour of creative and decently ambitious and exciting found footage, then go ahead. Just know that it takes awhile for things to start. If you're looking for visual aliens, this really doesn't offer any probably so they could save on the budget which must have been pretty low. On the whole, 'Area 51', has a presentable start with more engaging use of the found footage, but it falls to the same issues and ends up like the rest without accomplishing much, but given the exciting story set-up, Peli really should have given us a whole lot more than just another camcorder film. In fairness, I think some people will enjoy this. I did not! Trust me there are some good movies out there for example REC (Just 1 & 2) Cloverfield, V/H/S series, Grave Encounters (the original & the sequel), The Tunnel Movie, & of course the original Paranormal Activity trilogy (not the shameful sequels). Disappointing!
so crazy, just skip to when they get into the base.

Not good !!! Very disappointing

Area 51: Take a mildly interesting premise about a group of friends plotting to break into the infamous secret government facility in the Nevada desert, add the now hackneyed found footage genre and a deathly dull first half, and voila, low budget schlock. That said, there were a few interesting moments in the last half hour, just not enough to make it worthwhile. C-

Area 51 goes a long way to convince us of its authenticityIts and its premise is irresistible but it doesn't lend itself to many satisfying scares and certainly no enough to compensate for its 5 year release.

Area 51 is everything that's wrong with not only found footage films, but also weak-minded sci-fi thrillers that think crazed talking heads and fuzzy shadows are scary enough. To be fair, the slow burn does eventually catch fire and there's lots of screaming and heavy breathing and dark tunnels and running and what-not. The relatively tense final half-hour is clearly the reason that very smart producer Jason Blum thought this would be a solid follow-up to "Paranormal Activity." It's that first hour that is the reason it took six years to (barely) get released.  There's no tension or action for the longest time and "Area 51" might have been better served as a short film or episode of an anthology series in that the entire first-hour of set-up could have been cut to five minutes. It makes sense for Area 51 to try and replicate the Paranormal Activity formula. Peli wanted another hit, so he repeats himself here, only instead of ghosts and darkness, there are aliens and darkness. Peli tacks an abrupt ending on the same film that caused over five years of grief and countless days of edits, re-edits, and obvious uncertainty. There's no creative leap to enjoy and little filmmaking finesse to study. Instead, it's more of the same, and in the five years "Area 51" has been sitting on the shelf, every studio and aspiring horror moviemaker has beaten Peli at his own game.

Absolutely HORRENDOUS. There's a reason Area 51, Oren Peli's follow-up to Paranormal Activity, has been sitting on the shelf for 9 years..... This could be the most boring "horror" movie imaginable. NOTHING happens. It's a dark, grainy, tedious, dumb, totally unsatisfying experience. Skip it by all means.

In 2009, Oren Peli all but reinvented the indie/found footage horror film with his sequel-spawning Paranormal Activity.  I'll remember the experience of seeing that film for the first time for as long as I live; sans expectations, I sauntered into the screening happy as a bird...then wobbled out 90 minutes later on shaky knees.  Watching two people sleeping and an invisible demon on the market for a human body to call home was apparently enough to break me.  Peli had tapped into horror's golden mantra - that less is more - and executed it to perfection.  Nothing happens in Paranormal Activity, yet it's one of the most effective horror films in recent years; the sound of footsteps slowly ascending the stairs or the mere accentuation of a static buzz, alluding to the next 'scare', is enough to destroy at least your next three nights' sleep.

Now we have Area 51, Peli's long-delayed and anticipated (in some corners, at least) follow-up about a group of kids planning to break into the eponymous base and discover some of the American government's most closely guarded secrets.  The film sets itself up in pretty much the same way every found-footage flick does nowadays: three guys, one of whom unrealistically films everything they do, and a pretty girl who enters the frame later on and clearly has a stronger connection with one of said guys than the other two.  Remember Earth To Echo, or Project Almanac?  Exactly the same formula.  But at least they were better films.

Even in attempting to look at this from a stand-alone perspective, i.e. ignoring Paranormal Activity completely, it's a hugely underwhelming experience.  Whether it's nitpicking or fatal, there are simply too many problems breaking up whatever semblance of a structure it has.  For starters, the characters are idiots.  Case in point: they've just broken into someone's house - someone whom they know to have been tangibly responsible for an ex-Area 51 employee's death - so what do they do?  Continue filming, of course.  When you're hiding behind a shower curtain with the house's owner mere inches away, of course you keep your blinking camera on.  But do they at least wear gloves? I hear you ask.  Ha!  Of course they don't.  One would be right assume they're smart enough to have a little moment and decide it's at least best to roll their sleeves down, but no.  Not even when they're IN AREA 51!  I mean, blimey.  Seriously?

More problematically, though, it isn't scary or thrilling.  Even slightly.  Perhaps Peli's intentions this time are less geared towards getting under his audiences' skin, which certainly feels like the case throughout, but if so, what are his intentions?  What kind of response is he attempting to elicit?  What is he actually trying to do with this film?  It takes about 70 minutes for something to actually happen involving the mysteries of Area 51.  When it does, it's unclear how we're supposed to react.  It feels like, despite the delays in getting this thing made, they still weren't sure how they wanted the third act to play out; what they wanted the kids to find.  It's rushed and generic with nothing to evoke even a little excitement.  Essentially, the moment the kids get into Area 51 is the moment the film truly dies.  How's that for depressing?

 ~May 16, 2015~

The minimalist approach surprisingly creates an involving trip, although it's hampered with vague visual and unsatisfying conclusion Found footage genre hasn't found much success after the initial trend start with REC or Cloverfield. It attempts to create a more personal experience with first person view often falls flat with cumbersome shaky shots and unclear scenes. Area 51 suffers from the same exact problems and it stutters towards the end, but it also manages to set an occasionally interesting trip, especially in the first half.

Story follows Reid and his friends as he tries to infiltrate the highly secured titular facility. To do so he must investigate the area and bypass many security measures. For most early parts, the film delivers quite the ride as audiences follow these guys on Vegas and its surrounding. Some investigations and interviews set the tone right, and not in overly silly way. Characters are also pretty decent and likeable as though they are real life friends.

Unfortunately, it soon arrives at familiar territory of hazy shots and mindless running. The scenes in the city or desert are identifiable, but when it is stranded in dark corners, the movie loses the momentum significantly. Script is also numbingly bland as characters would yell the same thing over and over again, this is especially true when they are repeatedly shouting, "We gotta go". With both visual and audio decrease in quality, it just turns into a confusing escapade.

Cinematography is to be expected from this kind of found footage flick, it's rather elementary, but there are a few good shots with modified vision. At several scenes the film builds up the suspense pretty well, these are not all translated into thrilling moments. It almost seems like it has problems in latter half, resorting to cheap alien gimmick and nullifying its early decent production.

 Area 51 has a presentable start with more engaging use of the found footage, but it falls to the same issues and ends up like the rest without accomplishing much.

Paranormal Activity, only original,  is one of best horror films I've seen andI still worship to  Oren Peli, and I've been waiting more than a year for latest film to be released.  Disappointingly, that's ripoff of 2014 film called Alien Abduction, yet better than that latest film though they both made me fast-forward.  Mr. Peli should've stuck to less-cliché and his own low-budget-style tradition, except please don't make any sequel or alien crap before another one goes into an ocean of the silliness!  Take a chance to redeem yours, sir.  Think harder, for God's sake.
I'm not a fan of this style of movie anyway, but it's pretty much along the lines of Rendlesham Forest UFO/Hangar 10.  Some excitement in the last half hour, but not much.

There is something inherently intriguing about the subject matter Area 51 has to offer, one that's been keeping every conspiracy theorist in the country occupied for decades. In the hands of a director that turned a small ghost story into a critical and box office smash, you'd think he could make it work. But the characters in this film are so paper-thin, and the long-winded conversations about their plan, which take up most of the film, feels so tedious (it only feels that way 'cause you just don't care about any of the characters) that any sense of danger in what they're doing is tragically MIA. To its credit, things pick up once they've finally entered the base, but by then it's already wasted an hour of it's 90-minute run time. More importantly, you've wasted 90 minutes of your life.

Full review at http://silverscreenfanatic.com/2015/05/15/area-51/

It wasn't to bad of a movie weird and crazy cheesy but this is what everyone thinks is in Area 51 but do you really want to find out for sure may not be what you expect or worse are you really ready to believe?

This movie perfectly captures the intensely mysterious and intriguing vibe of Area 51. And surprisingly, upon my second viewing of this movie, I liked it even more. There are subtle details throughout the movie that foreshadow and somewhat explain the ending, which I loved. There are a couple of unnecessary scenes and a bit of iffy dialogue here and there. 
However, this movie was overall quite intriguing, tense, and very well made. And the last 30 minutes? Mind blowing, visually and mentally. Any patient and geeky mind will love this movie.

For Oren Peli's Area 51, I was actually pretty excited to see it as he is directing and writing another film after the first Paranormal Activity. He wrote Chernobyl Diaries which was terrible, but it was also written by the Van Dyke brothers which one of them has written the Asylum DVDs, so I didn't blame entirely on Oren Peli. So when it didn't came out for years, I did start to forget about it, until I saw that it was on Netflix which I was very curious about Area 51. As it turns out, Area 51 is not as groan inducing as Chernobyl Diaries, but it might as well be forgotten. The acting is not nearly as good in this as in the director's previous film Paranormal Activity, and is just average. The characters are lacking any development that I didn't care about anyone or wanting them to survive. The first hour of it is so boring that I kept looking at how much progress I got into it many times. Most of the time I get why it's being filmed, but there's times that makes no sense about why it's being filmed, and that it could've made a bit better if it wasn't found footage. Things actually start to happen in the last 30 minutes which there are some cool effects in it, but even that was lacking in thrills. I like that there's no jump scares, but it doesn't do anything remotely scary that I start to wonder if it was even a horror film at all. It has an unnecessary ending that is just like any other horror film. For Chernobyl Diaries, there can be a good horror film from it which frustrated me that it was not good, but for Oren Peli's Area 51, I can't see how they can make a effective horror film and is just plain forgettable.

Despite it's compelling (if by now overdone) premise and Oren Peli's competent direction. Area 51 is a thinly scripted, overlong and mostly fright less sophomore film that stayed on the shelf too long, and feels tired and pointless now.
Boring movie and I didn't thought anything interesting about it!
Interesting for about 30 minutes.  Just seemed to drag on after that.  I think I fell asleep for the last 20 minutes or so...don't plan on going back to watch it.
